++Tcv+: This is an uncommon client authentication failure type, which happens when the client sends a different Identifier in the Response and Request messages.
+Cc4k7:
{serverType} servers are prioritized for the following:

{disabledList}.

In order to delete {count, plural, one {this} other {these}} {serverType} {count, plural, one {server} other {servers}} you must define a different method.
+moBZd: Reboot due to mesh mode change or country code change
/+G1qq: Connectivity is failing because the security type (cipher suite) requested by the client is not valid or is not supported by the AP/WLAN. This problem may be caused by new 802.11 connection mechanisms that have incomplete or problematic client-side implementations that lead to compatibility issues.
/9+YKH:
JP-

Format options:

Most secured - all printable ASCII characters can be used

Keyboard friendly - only letters and numbers will be used

Numbers only - only numbers will be used
/f0cXL: HT or VHT rate set mismatch
/zC7P0: JP-DHCP failures are unusually high in {scope}
0Hd1cr: JP-Allow users to access the network without any authentication/security (not recommended)
0R5z1l:
System has detected an abnormally high number of AP reboots. This can occur due to the following reasons:

  1. Insufficient power from the Power over Ethernet (PoE) switch or PoE injector device aka. Power Sourcing Equipment (PSE).
  2. Configuration download failures.
  3. Firmware update failures.
  4. System initiated reboots.
0ceRGX: PoE power has been denied due to power exhaustion or because another high priority device is plugged in.
1IGVC6: This disconnect issue is happening because clients are disconnected because they are sending unsupported frames (i.e. Class2) before forming a valid open authentication.
1WCywA:
Clients are failing at the authentication stage of an 802.11r (Fast Transition) roam. The client is including PMKID information from its roam-from AP, but the roam-to AP does not have the key.

This scenario is most commonly caused in the following scenarios:

  1. The roam-from and roam-to APs cannot share keys with one another, which happens if they are not RF neighbors or if they do not have IP connectivity for AP-to-AP communication.
  2. The roam-from and roam-to APs are not RF neighbors. Clients may assume that all APs sharing an SSID will have the key, but the key may only be shared with RF neighbors.
1uY0Dm:
Though this issue is uncommon, it may occur due to unexpected configuration changes or incompatibilities:

  1. Are the impacted clients configured to use a WLAN type that mismatches the AP/SSID settings?
  2. Were devices recently upgraded with new firmware?
  3. Was the WLAN configuration changed on the infrastructure?
2078fK: Cannot contain Exclamation mark(!) and space
218h0n: Clients are attempting to associate without first performing 802.11 open authentication. Typically this happens when the client/AP state machine is out of sync.
2bCYZp: Users are failing to successfully connect at the authentication stage. This connection failure issue is comprised of multiple failure types and reasons, making it difficult to pin down the exact cause.
34zaaY:
This behavior is uncommon in Wi-Fi and represents a protocol incompatibility. If clients are exhibiting this behavior, double-check the common situations that introduce interoperability problems like this:

  1. Were the firmware or drivers recently updated on impacted clients?
  2. Were new client types recently introduced into the environment?
3AWmVY: Users are failing to successfully connect at the 802.11 association stage. This connection failure issue is comprised of multiple failure types and reasons, making it difficult to pin down the exact cause.
3HBQtF: Station kicked out due to retries
3K5Y0C:
This problem should be uncommon, and is most likely caused by transient security state machine mismatch. If the problem persists, check for these common issues that may introduce behavior issues:

  1. Were new clients or APs introduced in the environment?
  2. Were the impacted client OS types recently upgraded?
  3. Was the AP firmware recently upgraded?
  4. Were the AP radio or WLAN settings recently modified?
3Spwog: JP-AP(s) operating in Low Power Mode: {scope}.
43C/hj: MAC Authentication provides an additional level of security for corporate networks. Client MAC Addresses are passed to the configured RADIUS servers for authentication and accounting. Note that changing this option requires to re-create the network (no edit option)
47SgpC: Not allow to change Venue on DHCP AP.
4RbqN8: JP-No venues activating this network. Use the ON/OFF switches in the list to select the activating venues
4Xs/u5:
This WPA Information Element mismatch issue is an uncommon issue in the 4-way handshake. If this is happening, packet captures may be required to investigate the nature of Information Element mismatches.

If the problem persists, check common situations that may have introduced this interoperability behavior:

  1. Are the impacted clients using problematic drivers or firmware?
  2. Was the firmware recently updated on impacted clients so as to introduce interoperability issues?
  3. Were new client types recently introduced into the environment?
4fOqW7: One of the values you entered conflicts with an existing accounting server configuration in another network.
4ldizo: JP-{scope} is experiencing unusually high CPU usage
53VZpT: The time-series graph on the left displays the percentage of DHCP connection attempts that have completed successfully. A DHCP connection attempt is deemed successful when the Wifi client has received an IP address from the DHCP server. Do note that a single Wifi client could have multiple DHCP connection attempts.{br}{br}The bar chart on the right captures the daily percentage over the last 7 days of the selected time range. Do note that the numbers related to the time-series graph will change as you zoom in/out of a time range, whereas the bar chart will stay fixed based on the selected time range at the top of the page.
5gTKDx: The IP addresses you entered conflict with existing authentication and accounting server configuration in another network. Please change the IP address.
5gkDFW: Cannot contain double quote and space
6JiLXT:
Clients are failing 802.1X/EAP authentication, which is typically caused by:

  1. Invalid EAP (PEAP or TTLS) username and password.
  2. Invalid EAP certificates.
  3. Expired or untrusted server certificates.
76jC1v: JP-This value should be higher than or equal to $'{min}'
7IpYkA: AssocReq WPA IE Mismatch with Msg 2 of 4
7fuwrN:
Users are experiencing a higher time to connect compared to the configured SLA goal. User's Wi-Fi connection process goes through several stages. Delays in any of the stages will result in a higher time to connect for the user.

  1. 802.11 authentication, association.
  2. 802.11 re-association in case of roaming
  3. L2/L3 authentication - Typical with 802.1x WLAN when RADIUS server is configured
  4. DHCP
7tSsC/:
This issue is typically the result of an intended policy configuration. No action may be needed, but if this behavior is creating unwanted user disruption, consider modifying the policy configurations:

  1. Confirm the L2 MAC ACL policy.
  2. Confirm the Blocked Client List.
8hHLAJ: Might be caused by network stability issues.
8lHXaF: JP-DHCP failures are high in {scope} impacting connectivity for {impact} of clients.
8xLJKq: Provides IP address to end devices
9Fc19F: Provides "portal" for guest access. Includes hotspot access (Passpoint, OpenRoaming)
9VIDP4: The username may only be known if the user has successfully passed authentication
APcLKh:
The RADIUS server is offline or unreachable from RUCKUS Cloud/AP (message from RUCKUS Cloud/AP to RADIUS is failing), which is often caused by:

  1. AP/SZ misconfiguration (Bad IP, bad port).
  2. The RADIUS server is offline.
  3. The RADIUS server is unreachable on the network (e.g. network path or routing issues).
Ajj55k: System has detected VLAN mismatches in your network. This is usually caused by misses during the VLAN configuration process.
BCBdiT: This issue is caused by a DoS protection feature, which can be enabled/disabled in the RUCKUS UI. If the behavior is having an undesirable impact on valid clients, the feature can be disabled or optimized to make the prevention logic more conservative.
BKadru:
In many cases with authentication failure, each client device behaves differently, which causes a variety of unique failure symptoms. If the problem is affecting many users or lasting for a long time, it may be helpful to double-check any recent changes:

  1. Credential changes.
  2. Bulk expiry of passwords.
  3. Certificate changes.
  4. Infrastructure changes.
  5. Introduction of new client device types, or software upgrades of existing clients.
Bi+2ZQ: The connection was not completed because the client has left, or is leaving, the network.
C28EQ8: Cannot be composed of ALL digits, e.g., 12345
C5Rw0o: JP-Use the controller as proxy in 802.1X networks. A proxy AAA server is used when APs send authentication/accounting messages to the controller and the controller forwards these messages to an external AAA server.
CHeh2t: A connection is deemed successful when a Wifi client is able to complete the 802.11 authentication, association, L2 authentication and receives an IP address from the DHCP. If any of these stages fail, it is considered as a failed connection. For L3 authentication, such as WISPr and captive portal authentication, since the Wifi client will receive an IP address before the L3 authentication, the client connection will be deemed successful before the L3 authentication completes.{br}{br}The time-series graph on the left displays the percentage of successful connections across time, and the bar chart on the right captures the daily percentage over the last 7 days of the selected time range. Do note that the numbers related to the time-series graph will change as you zoom in/out of a time range, whereas the bar chart will stay fixed based on the selected time range at the top of the page.
CHxHdT: The time-series graph on the left displays the percentage of 802.11 authentication attempts that has completed successfully. 802.11 authentication is the first step in establishing a WiFi connection, and it requires a WiFi client to establish its identity as a valid 802.11 device with an AP. No data encryption or security is available at this stage, and it is not to be confused with WPA or 802.1X authentication.{br}{br}The bar chart on the right captures the daily percentage over the past 7 days. Do note that the numbers related to the time-series graph will change as you zoom in/out of a time range, whereas the histogram will stay constant based on the selected date range at the top of the page.
CPn6si: JP-802.11 Authentication failures are unusually high in {scope}
CY1L4I:
If the problem does not resolve on its own, check the infrastructure and client population for recent changes likely to produce this failure:

  1. Were new clients or APs introduced in the environment?
  2. Were the impacted client OS types recently upgraded?
  3. Was the AP firmware recently upgraded?
  4. Were the AP radio or WLAN settings recently modified?
D/k1T1: JP-Clients with low RSS are unusually high in {scope}, impacting {impact} of connected clients.
D4bMOH: Can be a single VLAN ID, a VLAN ID range or a combination of both, separated with commas e.g. 1,3,5-7
DNSfqE: High AP-RUCKUS Cloud connection failures in {scope}
DUpLCq:
This behavior may be a desirable consequence of the admin's configuration-to prevent any one AP from serving too many clients. If so, no action is needed.

If this issue is having an undesirable client impact, there are a few possible recommendations:

  1. If the max configured limit is too low, change the SSID or AP radio settings to increase the max number of allowed clients.
  2. If there is a very high amount of client transience and the SSID's client inactivity timeout is set too high, the AP may be honoring clients that are no longer connected. Reduce the inactivity timeout on the SSID.
  3. If band or load balancing are disabled, consider enabling them to more proactively spread client load across service sets.
  4. If the RF design allows for it, add APs to supplement capacity.
E+AiRv:
The user's connectivity is failing at DHCP because the server is unable to satisfy the client's request. This may be caused by one of several reasons:

  1. The server received duplicate DHCP requests from the same client.
  2. The client is requesting an address on an incorrect subnet.
  3. There may be more than one DHCP server replying to the same client.
Emb+jc:
This disconnect reason can be difficult to troubleshoot because the reason is unspecified and may be initiated by the AP or client. Some high-level troubleshooting guidance follows:

  1. Check for isolated areas of impact in the network (e.g. a specific WLAN, client OS, AP model, AP group, etc) with unique settings or behavior that may be causing this.
  2. Check for recent OS upgrades or configuration changes that are having isolated impact.
  3. Check the client troubleshooting page for impacted clients (see Client Impact details below) to diagnose the failure stage in the connection flow.
Ez/ZY3: The time to connect (TTC) measures the total time taken for a Wifi client to successfully go through all the required stages in order to establish a IP connection, namely 802.11 authentication, association, L2 authentication, and receiving an IP address from the DHCP. For L3 authentication, such as WISPr and captive portal authentication, since the Wifi client will receive an IP address before the L3 authentication, the time to connect does not include the time taken for L3 authentication.{br}{br}The time-series graph on the left displays the percentage of successful connections across time that meet the configured TTC SLA. Bar chart on the right displays the distribution of TTC. Do note that the numbers related to the time-series graph will change as you zoom in/out of a time range, whereas the bar chart will stay fixed based on the selected time range at the top of the page.
EzTaEJ: Dropped auth frame by Transient Client Management
F3C5Zx: JP-{key,select,name{{entityName} with that name already exists} other{{entityName} with that value already exists}}
FRpcYr: This failure typically represents a behavioral bug in which a frame includes an information element that does not conform to 802.11 specifications.
FwxRgx: The client connection exchange is failing because of a group key update timeout. Group keys are refreshed on a regular interval and should not typically interrupt the connection process.
Fx+OK0: This failure happens when the message integrity check (MIC) of connection frames fails, typically due to keying errors or expiration, or during passphrase authentication failures.
GHbJKA:
This state machine mismatch problem happens somewhat regularly in Wi-Fi as a transient problem, but is usually self-corrected by the client/AP. If the problem is having a noticeable impact on user connectivity, double-check the common situations that introduce misbehavior like this:

  1. Was the firmware recently updated on the infrastructure or impacted clients?
  2. Were new client types recently introduced into the environment, and are they Wi-Fi certified?
GLV1Lq: JP-Use 802.1X standard and WPA2 security protocols to authenticate users using an authentication server on thenetwork
GTySz+:
This behavior is uncommon in Wi-Fi and represents a protocol incompatibility. If clients are exhibiting this behavior, double-check the common situations that introduce interoperability problems like this:

  1. Were the firmware or drivers recently updated on the infrastructure or impacted clients?
  2. Were new client types recently introduced into the environment, and are they able to support the AP's WLAN security types?
GUGtP5: Clients are disconnected during the connection sequence, but the reason is unknown and unspecified by the disconnecting device.
GgGw+A: Enter the native VLAN ID (no VLAN tag in its Ethernet frames)
H7QJsZ: No WPA/RSN IE in Assoc Req
HUTzkq: Connectivity is failing because the security type (Robust Security Network (RSN)) requested by the client is not valid or is not supported by the AP/WLAN. This problem may be caused by new 802.11 connection mechanisms that have incomplete or problematic client-side implementations that lead to compatibility issues.
HX3vfn: JP-The controller cluster is sending data with an incorrect future timestamp. To avoid false or misleading data analysis, all future timestamped data is dropped.
Hab5wQ: Connectivity is failing because the security type (authentication and key management protocol (AKMP)) requested by the client is not valid or is not supported by the AP/WLAN. This problem may be caused by new 802.11 connection mechanisms that have incomplete or problematic client-side implementations that lead to compatibility issues.
HsFqgS:
To remediate the problems identified above, follow the corresponding recommended actions:

  1. Test network connection between AP and RUCKUS Cloud.
  2. Ensure that there is clear communication on all required ports.
  3. Test WAN connection health to ensure there is a route from AP to RUCKUS Cloud and there is no or acceptable packet loss.
  4. Ensure that AP certificate is valid. Work with Ruckus customer support to identify and resolve this condition.
I/yBco: This incident impacted {count} {count, plural, one {WLAN} other {WLANs} }
I44QmF: Only one record can be selected for editing!
I5d+Q5:
To resolve this issue, you may need to check RADIUS log details for authentication reject messages.

Recent changes in the authentication infrastructure may cause a sudden spike of EAP failures like this:

  1. RADIUS server certificate changes or expiration.
  2. Mass user password changes or credential expiry.
  3. Client onboarding or provisioning with wrong our outdated trust or credential profiles.
ILVg4S: Users are failing to successfully connect at the RADIUS stage. This connection failure issue is comprised of multiple failure types and reasons, making it difficult to pin down the exact cause.
JGFtqZ: This incident impacted {count} {count, plural, one {client manufacturer} other {client manufacturers} }
JKnT12: JP-The controller cluster is sending data with an incorrect past timestamp. To avoid false or misleading data analysis, past timestamped data is not analyzed for incidents.
JNRYDN: Clients are failing 802.11r roaming due to a mismatch in the mobility domain ID (MDID) in the 802.11r connection request.
JU41ei:
To remediate the problems identified above, follow the corresponding recommended actions:

  1. Check the peer device configuration. It should match with AP WAN Port capacity.
  2. Check the peer device capacity for supporting multi gig throughput.
  3. Check the cable for good Ethernet link negotiation.
JfSEkt: JP-RADIUS failures are high in {scope} impacting connectivity for {impact} of clients.
K9PPzT: Client connections are temporarily suppressed by Transient Client Management behavior configured on the WLAN.
Kj0P8X: You selected CLI profiles with overlapping switch models. Please correct your selection
L1p24z: The time-series graph on the left displays the percentage of EAP attempts (consisting the 4-way handshake between client and AP) that have completed successfully. An EAP attempt is deemed successful when all the necessary handshakes are completed. Do note that a single Wifi client could have multiple EAP attempts.{br}{br}The bar chart on the right captures the daily percentage over the last 7 days of the selected time range. Do note that the numbers related to the time-series graph will change as you zoom in/out of a time range, whereas the bar chart will stay fixed based on the selected time range at the top of the page.
L3NiJZ:
System has detected the AP(s) are underperforming w.r.t WiFi Radio spatial streams due to insufficient power available on PoE port. This can occur due to following reasons:

  1. Insufficient power from the Power over Ethernet (PoE) switch or PoE injector device aka. Power Sourcing Equipment (PSE).
  2. Faulty cables, Wrong cable types and very long cables can lead to power deterioration supplied to AP.
L84G40: JP-The controller cluster is sending data with an incorrect past timestamp
LJY1PV: Clients are failing authentication (4-way handshake) because the AP is receiving EAPOL keys (typically msg2 or msg4) from clients in an incorrect sequence.
Lk4Mip: Clients are failing authentication because the passphrase (PSK) does not match the AP/SSID configuration.
Lpfnla: One of the values you entered conflicts with an existing authentication server configuration in another network.
Ls00yh: JP-{scope} is experiencing unusually high CPU usage. Prolonged high usage can cause CPU tasks to be queued, and also impact sending of data to northbound systems, including, but not limited to, RUCKUS Analytics.
Lxa/r0:
Increase power capacity by adding a second power supply or add additional switches if the switch doesn't have pluggable power supply. If the switch is part of a stack, connect the device to a different switch in the stack based on proximity.

  1. If there is no more room for adding power supplies either due to the switch type or all the power supply slots are used, increase power capacity by adding additional switches because there is no room to add more power supplies.
  2. If the switch has room for more power supplies, increase power capacity by adding a second power supply.
M4esmj: The time-series graph on the left displays the percentage of RADIUS authentication attempts that have completed successfully. A RADIUS authentication attempt is deemed successful when all the necessary handshakes in the RADIUS protocol are completed, and the client is either allowed or denied access. Do note that a single Wifi client could have multiple authentication attempts.{br}{br}The bar chart on the right captures the daily percentage over the last 7 days of the selected time range. Do note that the numbers related to the time-series graph will change as you zoom in/out of a time range, whereas the bar chart will stay fixed based on the selected time range at the top of the page.
MOwOvp: Designated APs in this venue are running the DHCP Server instance. Typically configured when multiple APs are at the same site and roaming across APs is needed
MWnWBw: Client throughput measures the down link throughput estimate of the client, taking into consideration RF channel conditions, interference, channel contention and client capabilities.{br}{br}The time-series graph on the left displays the percentage of Wifi sessions across time that have a client throughput that meet the configured SLA. The bar chart on the right displays the distribution of the client throughput. Do note that the numbers related to the time-series graph will change as you zoom in/out of a time range, whereas the bar chart will stay fixed based on the selected time range at the top of the page.
Mu/Odk: JP-EAP failures are unusually high in {scope}
NL+Vrv: Impacted clients are failing association because of a DoS prevention feature that temporarily blocks their connections after they have excessive authentication failures in a short period of time.
NoVNdx: Reboot due to mesh enablement or country code change
O0k4eg: Dropped auth frame by blocked client
OF3pml: This issue happens when the client begins a connection attempt, but leaves the BSS before the connection is complete.
OiCFHC: Clients are failing authentication because of key data errors in msg2 of the 4-way handshake (sent from client to AP). This may be caused by cipher/key incompatibilities or invalid key data.
Om9Mvg:
To remediate the problems identified above, follow the corresponding recommended actions:

  1. This stage typically does not contribute to delays. Delays in this stage might indicates RF issues. Try changing channel or band.
  2. Delays in this stage might indicate roaming issues. User device may be trying to connect to far off APs. Try changing channel or band.
  3. (Typical) Delays in this stage might indicate high latency to the RADIUS server or an overloaded RADIUS server. Inspect RADIUS server configuration, isolate the component with high network latency or try dedicating CPU, memory, and disk to the RADIUS server if it is hosted on a shared VM.
  4. (Typical) If there is high latency in receiving the DHCP response or if the DHCP response is not received it can add significant delays to the connection process. Common causes are overloaded DHCP server - DHCP server IP pool exhaustion or DHCP server not able to keep up with the rate of incoming DHCP requests. Inspect DHCP server configuration and assign dedicated CPU, memory, disk space to the DHCP server.
P0c/ms: One of the values you entered conflicts with existing authentication and accounting server configurations in another network.
PJMqbz:
Some modest DHCP NAKs are normal in every network (e.g. client device sent duplicate DHCP Requests), but excessive DHCP failures with a NAK may be resolved by checking common DHCP server configuration or network design problems:

  1. Did the WLAN's IP subnet recently change, and is now causing DHCP renewal failures?
  2. Is there a new L3 network boundary where devices are roaming and failing to renew their prior IP address?
  3. If two DHCP servers are serving the same subnet, ensure they are properly configured for load balancing or passive standby.
PL8DeQ: AP lost connection to gateway for more than 1800 seconds
PMVvkt:
To remediate the problems identified above, follow the corresponding recommended actions:

  1. Consider turning on auto channel selection algorithms - Background scan or ChannelFly.
  2. If ChannelFly is selected it is mandatory to turn ON background scan.
  3. If static channel assignment is desired consider reducing Channelization to 20MHz / 40MHz.
  4. Scan your environments for rogue APs and remove them if possible.
  5. In the Zone/ AP group configuration, remove DFS channels with excessive DFS events.
PQgDLT: The time-series graph on the left displays the percentage of association attempts that have completed successfully. An association attempt is deemed successful when the Wifi client receives an Association ID from the AP. It is normal for a single Wifi client to have more than one association attempts.{br}{br}The bar chart on the right captures the daily percentage over the last 7 days of the selected time range. Do note that the numbers related to the time-series graph will change as you zoom in/out of a time range, whereas the bar chart will stay fixed based on the selected time range at the top of the page.
Pbb+rM:
This is a common problem in networks where passphrase authentication (e.g. WPA2-Personal) is used. To resolve the issue, check the following:

  1. Was the passphrase recently changed on the infrastructure, while client devices still used the old passphrase?
  2. Was there a spike of new users who may have been provided with the wrong passphrase?
  3. Were client devices provisioned automatically with device management software with the wrong passphrase?
PzXpbh:
This invalid key sequence issue happens in Wi-Fi as a transient problem, but is usually self-corrected by the client/AP. If the problem is having a noticeable impact on user connectivity, double-check the common situations that introduce misbehavior like this:

  1. Was the AP's airtime utilization excessively high during the failure window? Busy RF conditions may manifest in this way.
  2. Was the firmware recently updated on impacted clients so as to introduce interoperability issues?
  3. Were new client types recently introduced into the environment?
Q1ylRq: {count} {count, plural, one {reason} other {reasons} } contributed to this incident
RrBlvY:
Check for common areas of PSK authentication delay in the network:

  1. If the WLAN is utilizing external DPSK, check the latency between the AP and the authentication store.
  2. If the WLAN is utilizing a normal PSK or internal DPSK, this problem should not occur under normal performance situations. Check for RF contention or interference to see if the environment is causing frame errors and delays.
S3VrmZ:
The RADIUS authentication exchange is failing because of a timeout waiting for a response from the RADIUS server. This is typically caused by the following reasons:

  1. The RADIUS server is offline.
  2. The RADIUS server is unreachable by RUCKUS Cloud/APAP (network reliability issues, like congestion, drops, flapping links, etc).
  3. The RADIUS server is overloaded and unable to reply.
  4. The wireless link is experiencing high congestion, retries/errors, or other unreliability issues.
SNxApV:
This may be caused if the roaming boundary for an SSID crosses two AP zones, venues, or groups in which the same SSID exists, but the MDID does not match on the SSIDs. Double check the deployment to identify if the failing AP(s) represent a roaming boundary between two WLANs that have the same SSID, but different MDIDs (usually between AP zones or venue).

This issue may be observed when client 802.11r implementations are unreliable, which usually points to firmware or driver issues. Check the impacted client list to see if this is only affecting a specific OS type.
SWOBSx: Clients are failing to connect during the association stage, but the exact reason for the failures is unclear.
Se22H1: JP-Please enter a valid IP address
T0/74h: JP-RADIUS failures are unusually high in {scope}
TJOQoX:
This state machine mismatch problem happens somewhat regularly in Wi-Fi as a transient problem, but is usually self-corrected by the client/AP. If the problem is having a noticeable impact on user connectivity, double-check the common situations that introduce misbehavior like this:

  1. Was the firmware recently updated on impacted clients?
  2. Were new client types recently introduced into the environment?
TP9LC9: This problem should be a transient issue in a network if many clients leave at the same time; but, it is usually associated with disconnect events, and should not impact connection attempts. If it does, this may be a data issue that can be reported to RUCKUS Support if it persists in your network.
TcVF+X: Please check the network routing, NIC to the switch, cable/medium between SZ nodes, upstream device interface hardware settings (duplex, speed, etc.) or interface errors, saturation status and upstream device port status as well.
TfAXIA: RUCKUS Dynamic Pre Shared Key Service
Tflm+8:
In many cases with RADIUS failure, each client device or RADIUS server behaves differently, which causes a variety of unique failure symptoms. If the problem is affecting many users or lasting for a long time, it may be helpful to validate the end-to-end RADIUS setup and network performance:

  1. Check the RADIUS server and RUCKUS Cloud settings to identify matching configurations (IP address, port, and shared secret).
  2. Check for RADIUS reachability by RUCKUS Cloud/APAP (network reliability issues, like congestion, drops, flapping links, etc).
  3. Check for recent changes in the RADIUS infrastructure that may be leading to issues.
  4. Check RADIUS performance metrics to ensure it has sufficient capacity and is not overloaded.
  5. Check the wireless link for high congestion, retries/errors, or other unreliability issues.
TgLtSR: Provides voice calling service over WiFi
TtsWJ7: Reboot due to firmware download failure
TzOlQm: JP-No leading or trailing spaces allowed
U+7zaY: JP-The controller cluster is sending data with an incorrect future timestamp
UOtY4N: Clients are attempting to associate without first performing 802.11 open authentication, or if the prior open authentication has expired. Typically this happens when the client/AP state machine is out of sync.
Ui4lDR:
DHCP timeouts will be resolved by isolating the DHCP server issue or network implementation problem:

  1. Is the DHCP server online with scopes configured and available addresses?
  2. Is the DHCP server available and reachable by clients with minimal latency?
  3. Are the APs (where failures are happening) and their switch ports properly configured with VLANs?
  4. Is the DHCP helper IP address properly configured on the subnet gateway?
VFny+X: Not available in this Beta version
VaMt0P: Please enter a valid subnet mask
W/8riE:
System has detected the AP(s) are underperforming due to low WAN bandwidth availability. This can occur due to following reasons:

  1. Upstream peer device configuration is wrong and not matching as per AP Ethernet WAN port capacity.
  2. Upstream peer device cannnot support multi gig throughput needed by APs.
  3. Faulty cables and incorrect cable types can lead to Ethernet link not negotiated properly.
WCrt3+: Reboot due to mesh mode change
WIdA6/: The time-series graph on the left displays the percentage of client sessions with average RSS that has met the configured SLA. The bar chart on the right captures the distribution of the RSS. Do note that the numbers related to the time-series graph will change as you zoom in/out of a time range, whereas the bar chart will stay fixed based on the selected time range at the top of the page.
X5ZcOD: AP capacity measures the downlink saturated throughput estimate of the AP radios, taking into consideration the RF channel conditions, interference, channel contention and client capabilities.{br}{br}The time-series graph on the left displays the percentage of AP capacity samples across time that meets the configured SLA. The bar chart on the right displays the distribution of AP capacity across the number of APs. Do note that the numbers related to the time-series graph will change as you zoom in/out of a time range, whereas the bar chart will stay fixed based on the selected time range at the top of the page.
XXmzTE: This metric measures the percentage of roaming attempts that have completed successfully. A roaming attempt is deemed successful when the Wifi client has its session transferred from one AP to the next. It is possible for a single Wifi client to have multiple roaming attempts.{br}{br}The bar chart on the right captures the daily percentage over the last 7 days of the selected time range. Do note that the numbers related to the time-series graph will change as you zoom in/out of a time range, whereas the bar chart will stay fixed based on the selected time range at the top of the page.
XZRi3V:
In these multi-issue failures, there are a few general recommendations to check:

  1. Were new clients or APs introduced in the environment?
  2. Were the impacted client OS types recently upgraded?
  3. Was the AP firmware recently upgraded?
  4. Were the AP radio or WLAN settings recently modified?
  5. Check for high levels of RF performance interference, which may be causing high error rates.
  6. Compare the configuration and operating deployment of the affected WLAN or network scope (AP, AP group, etc) with others to identify any unique settings that may be causing issues.
XwYgzD: Designated APs in this venue are running the DHCP Server instance. The DHCP server APs connected to the WAN, the rest of APs get their Private IP address from a local IP Pool with VLAN ID 1 from the DHCP Server AP
YLraaM: You must have at least one RADIUS or TACACS+ server set-up in order to enable authorization or accounting
YqxKme:
In most cases, clients will immediately fall back to a "slow roam" if 802.11r (FT) roams fail.

To enable 802.11r roaming, make sure that APs are able to communicate with their RF neighbors via the IP (wired) infrastructure.
ZLzqDd: Reboot due to country code change
ZjT8D6: The client(s) was actively disconnected due to an 802.11v BSS Transition Management (BTM) action to improve client load distribution.
ZqvXR5: Reboot due to WLAN migration or firmware download failure
ZtxCeY: JP-This value should be lower than or equal to $'{max}'
a0nN4F: Users are failing to successfully connect at the 802.11 authentication stage. This connection failure issue is comprised of multiple failure types and reasons, making it difficult to pin down the exact cause.
a3u/wa:
• Once CLI profiles are applied, the venue can no longer accept regular profiles
  • The selected CLI profiles cannot contain overlapping switch models
aRS8Am: VLAN ID must be between 1 and 4094
alYY14:
High CPU usage can occur due to many reasons. CPU spikes can also occur for short duration under normal operation. This incident is raised when sustained high CPU usage is detected. Smartzone CPU is used by multiple processes, services and applications. There are approximately 5 groups of applications.

  1. Messaging group: This consists of applications that process, store, distribute and export stats.
  2. Web group: This consists of the web server and other applications that process internal and external APIs.
  3. Event group: This mainly consists of services that handle events and alarms.
  4. WISPRr group: This consists of services that process user login/logout, session management etc.
  5. Device group: This mainly consists of AP and switch connection status management.

Sometimes memory intensive processes like downloading files or uploading firmwares might cause high CPU usage
aonhCk: This incident impacted {count} {count, plural, one {radio} other {radios} }
bZOjOB: Mesh AP cannot be moved to a different venue
bu6Csa:
Client uplink RSSI is unusually low, which can have several root causes. Consider the following common behavior and design issues:

  1. General under-coverage (insufficient APs), localized coverage holes, or sub-optimal AP placement.
  2. Conservative roaming behavior, also known as sticky clients (clients will not roam until their RSSI is very low).
  3. If this problem is only affecting certain client types or OS versions, client firmware or configuration settings may be leading to aggressive power save measures that decrease transmit power.
bvFsep: Clients are failing authentication because the WPA Information Element in msg2 of the 4-way handshake (sent from client to AP) does not match the WPA Information Element sent in the Association Request.
cye5/B: The hostname may only be known if the user has successfully obtained an IP address from DHCP
czpjyb: JP-Require users to enter a passphrase to connect. The passphrase is unique per device
d8o6Hc:
This incident can be caused due to the following reasons:

  1. An incorrect static channel configuration in Zone/AP Group may lead to APs in overlapping channels.
  2. High number of rogue APs in the RF environment may cause APs to select overlapping channels.
dQKcaA:
Client authentication is failing because of a timeout in the authentication exchange with the client. This is commonly caused by the following reasons:

  1. EAP Request timeout waiting for client EAP Response.
  2. 4-way handshake timeout waiting for the client response.
dnnI3G: JP-The network latency between the SZ nodes is unusually high
eVN5dK:
In these multi-issue failures, there are a few general recommendations to check:

  1. Were new clients or APs introduced in the environment?
  2. Were the impacted client OS types recently upgraded?
  3. Was the AP firmware recently upgraded?
  4. Were the AP radio or WLAN settings recently modified?
  5. Check for high levels of RF performance interference, which may be causing high error rates.
  6. Compare the configuration and operating deployment of the affected WLAN or network scope (AP, AP group, etc) with others to identify unique settings that may be causing issues.
ejDjCV:
To remediate the problems identified above, follow the corresponding recommended actions:

  1. Ensure that PSE (PoE switch or PoE injector) capacity is appropriately matching with deployed AP models power requirement.
  2. Check the cable length, cable type for good PoE use.
epNuT+: JP-802.11 Authentication failures are high in {scope} impacting connectivity for {impact} of clients.
ett4PX: Online APs measures the percentage of APs which are online and connected to Smart Zone.{br}{br}The time-series graph on the left displays the Online AP percentage across time. The bar chart on the right captures the daily Online AP percentage over the last 7 days of the selected time range. Do note that the numbers related to the time-series graph will change as you zoom in/out of a time range, whereas the bar chart will stay fixed based on the selected time range at the top of the page.
f3ccIk: Clients are failing association because the association request is missing the WPA/RSN information element(s), which typically indicates interoperability issues.
fA/xlX:
This problem should resolve on its own, but if it persists, check the infrastructure and client population for recent changes likely to produce this failure:

  1. Were new clients or APs introduced in the environment?
  2. Were the impacted client OS types recently upgraded?
  3. Was the AP firmware recently upgraded?
  4. Were the AP radio or WLAN settings recently modified?
fD7kFi: This disconnect issue is very uncommon, but may be caused if the AP is suffering from excessive performance load and cannot satisfy the client's connection request.
fHh7yn:
System has detected abnormally high memory utilization in the switch. At the current rate, the switch will reach threshold limit soon, as indicated in the graph.

Switch might run out of memory if the memory usage rate continues. This is typically indicative of a memory leak in the switch.

*Note: Threshold limit is auto-calculated by the system.
faDss4:
To fix this issue, it may be necessary to check the RADIUS server availability as well as the link between RUCKUS Cloud/AP and the RADIUS server.

If all services are up and functional, double-check the RADIUS configuration on RUCKUS Cloud/AP.
gVrnzq: Connectivity is failing because the security type (group cipher suite) from the client is not valid or is not supported by the AP/WLAN. This problem may be caused by new 802.11 connection mechanisms that have incomplete or problematic client-side implementations that lead to compatibility issues.
gjjYcv: Cannot contain Exclamation mark(!), double quotes and space
hDMRzb:
The password needs to:

  • Be 8 to 64 characters long
  • Include both uppercase and lowercase characters (ABC, xyz)
  • Include at least one number (0-9)
  • Include at least one symbol (@, #, $, %, etc. use of "!" is not allowed)
Password cannot:
  • Contain spaces
hLsp5G:
Clients are failing to associate due to one of the following permission features:

  1. The L2 MAC ACL settings do not permit this client (client MAC exists in denial list, or does not exist in permitted list).
  2. The client MAC is included in the blocked client list configured by the admin.
hdGKYY: JP-Require users to enter a passphrase (that you have defined for the network) to connect
hkHovQ:
This problem should self-correct when the client device actively uses the Wi-Fi network again. If the issue appears to be affecting active clients and is posing connectivity problems for users, check the following possible issues:

  1. Were new clients or APs introduced in the environment?
  2. Were the impacted client OS types recently upgraded?
  3. Was the AP firmware recently upgraded?
  4. Were the AP radio or WLAN settings recently modified?
hpExgW: Check and configure missing VLAN, or ensure type (untagged/tagged) match on both ends of the connection.
hvHylk: The time-series graph on the left displays the percentage of APs that have AP-to-SZ control plane latency which meets the configured SLA. The bar chart on the right captures the distribution of the latency across the number of APs. Do note that the numbers related to the time-series graph will change as you zoom in/out of a time range, whereas the bar chart will stay fixed based on the selected time range at the top of the page.
iChz4G: Each AP in this venue is running its own DHCP server instance. Typically configured when APs are at different sites and roaming is not required
iHlZH2:
If this issue does not resolve on its own, this is often a case of client compatibility issues, which may be caused by:

  1. Client software issues or upgrades.
  2. Recent configuration changes on the client authentication settings (username/password or identity settings).
iJ+fGj: You don't have permission to set threshold for selected network node.
ivPyUu: AP lost connection to controller for more than 14400 seconds
k5KI1E: Users are failing to successfully connect at the DHCP stage. This connection failure issue is comprised of multiple failure types and reasons, making it difficult to pin down the exact cause.
kaxley: AP-RUCKUS Cloud connection uptime measures the percentage of time the AP radios are fully available for client service. The time-series graph on the left displays the percentage of AP-RUCKUS Cloud connection uptime samples across time that meets the configured SLA. The bar chart on the right displays the distribution of AP service uptime across the number of APs. Do note that the numbers related to the time-series graph will change as you zoom in/out of a time range, whereas the bar chart will stay fixed based on the selected time range at the top of the page.
kcUzlc:
Client associations are failing on the AP due to one of several possible capacity conditions:

  1. The AP radio has reached its max client limit (fixed limit of HW/SW).
  2. The AP has reached its total client limit for both radios (fixed limit of HW/SW).
  3. The AP radio has reached its max allowed client limit, as specified by the admin in the configuration.
l/e8Fv: JP-AP(s) operating in Low Power Mode: {scope}
l4NqVU:
To remediate the problems identified above, follow the corresponding recommended actions:

  1. Consider turning on auto channel selection algorithms - Background scan or ChannelFly.
  2. If ChannelFly is selected it is mandatory to turn ON background scan.
  3. Scan your environments for rogue APs and remove them if possible.
l6kkAc: Configures VLAN tag usage for the port
l7HNFB: Reboot due to IP mode change or mesh enablement
lLyFJV: Connectivity is failing because the security type capabilities (Robust Security Network (RSN) Capabilities) requested by the client are not valid or are not supported by the AP/WLAN. This problem may be caused by new 802.11 connection mechanisms that have incomplete or problematic client-side implementations that lead to compatibility issues.
lNcpaa: Reboot due to IP mode change
leCm3C:
RADIUS timeouts are most likely to be resolved by investigating the RADIUS server health directly, typically by focusing on load or service availability metrics and logs:

  1. Is the RADIUS server reliable and reachable (by ping from the AP or RUCKUS Cloud)?
  2. Is the RADIUS server experiencing high load?
  3. Is the RADIUS hardware infrastructure (CPU, Memory, IO) over-loaded or otherwise suffering a service outage?
  4. Do the RADIUS logs indicate unusual failures messages or reasons?
  5. Is the wireless link showing symptoms of congestion (high airtime utilization or interference)?
ln7Utz: This issue is typically the result of an intended policy configuration. No action may be needed, but if this behavior is creating unwanted user disruption, consider disabling Transient Client Management or make the logic more conservative.
m6WOAM: The PoE Utilization measures the percentage of the switches that utilize less power than the goal set.{br}{br}The time-series graph on the left displays the percentage of switches across time that meet the configured SLA. The bar chart on the right captures the distribution of PoE Utilization across the number of switches. Do note that the numbers related to the time-series graph will change as you zoom in/out of a time range, whereas the bar chart will stay fixed based on the selected time range at the top of the page.
m8B9gB:
P3 - Contact RUCKUS Support.

P2 - Schedule a maintenance window and reboot the switch if the memory utilization continues to increase. Contact RUCKUS Support.

P1 - Schedule a maintenance window and reboot the switch if the memory utilization continues to increase. Contact RUCKUS Support.
mMBc1K:
This incident can be caused due to the following reasons:

  1. An incorrect static channel configuration in Zone/AP Group may lead to APs in overlapping channels.
  2. High number of rogue APs in the RF environment may cause APs to select overlapping channels.
  3. In 5 GHz band, APs might select overlapping channels to avoid channels with DFS events.
mQbCtp:
Management Frame Protection (MFP) is defined in 802.11w to protect 802.11 Robust Management frames, including Disassociation, Deauthentication, and Robust Action frames.
  • Optional allows legacy devices that do not support the 802.11w standard to associate with the SSID while also allowing devices that support 802.11w to use the 802.11w features.
  • Required will prevent clients that do not support 802.11w from associating.
mgHLcZ:
System has detected high number of AP-RUCKUS Cloud connection failures. This can occur due to following reasons:

  1. Intermittent or permanent loss of connectivity between AP and RUCKUS Cloud. Losing consecutive heartbeat/keepalive messages from the AP will result in AP-RUCKUS Cloud connection failures.
  2. Improperly configured Firewall or NAT device or a network switch can cause the AP-RUCKUS Cloud communication failure.
  3. Lack of reachability from AP to RUCKUS Cloud over a WAN connection or cloud would cause APs to disconnect from RUCKUS Cloud.
  4. In rare cases, AP certificate is invalid which forces RUCKUS Cloud to deny the incoming connection from the AP.
mpbHiW: JP-Association failures are unusually high in {scope}
mtg3Og: By default, will be used as the network SSID as well. Length is limited to 2-32 characters (depending on the language you use)
nUcJKL: Reboot due to WLAN migration or firmware change
nbyqr2: AP cannot find uplink and is in island state
noTj55:
To diagnose this issue further, check the following situations:

  1. High RF interference, airtime utilization, or other poor RF conditions, which disrupts normal channel access.
  2. Were the impacted client OS types recently upgraded?
  3. Were the WLAN settings (especially DPSK) recently modified?
nu+ICw: Clients are failing to connect during the 802.11 open authentication, but the exact reason for the failures is unclear.
nwViUa: JP-Association failures are high in {scope} impacting connectivity for {impact} of clients.
oAzpTF: Clients are failing in the 802.11 open authentication stage because the authentication algorithm in the authentication request is not supported by the WLAN/AP.
oTAW/k:
Given the broad set of potential reasons for low RSSI, the recommendation will be based on the actual root cause, including some of the following possibilities:

  1. In cases of general or localized under-coverage (all clients have low RSSI), add APs as needed.
  2. In cases of sub-optimal AP placement (sufficient APs, but localized coverage issues), consider re-locating APs based on RF design best practices or adding APs to supplement.
  3. In cases of sticky clients, consider utilizing features like SmartRoam to assist clients with proactive roaming guidance (first, double-check to see if clients support 802.11v, or if the sticky client issue is affecting application performance).
  4. In cases where low tx power is affecting only a subset of clients, check for unique configuration settings regarding power save, or potentially firmware upgrades that resolve client-side tx issues.
ozB49A: Assoc reject by software internal error
ozC+ck: Connectivity is failing because the management frame information elements from the client are not valid or is not supported by the AP/WLAN. This problem may be caused by new 802.11 connection mechanisms that have incomplete or problematic client-side implementations that lead to compatibility issues.
p9cc+P: Name must be between 2 and 32 alpha-numeric characters. Backtick "`" and the "$(" combination are not allowed.
pJVOdI: JP-AP service is affected due to high number of AP reboots.
pR9NkG: WPA2 is strong Wi-Fi security that is widely available on all mobile devices manufactured after 2006. WPA2 should be selected unless you have a specific reason to choose otherwise.
pa7dvf: Invalid Key Data in EAPOL-Key Msg 2 of 4
pq900d: Client connection attempts are failing because the device is attempting to use a previously expired authentication key management (AKM) credential. This issue should be a transient problem in the network and should self-correct.
q2wzm3: JP-Time to connect is high in {scope}, impacting connectivity for {impact} of clients.
q5IqDv: {count} {count, plural, one {event type} other {event types} } contributed to this incident
q8tzQn: JP-Clients with low RSS are unusually high in {scope}
qBnfE9:
* The following LAN Port settings cant work because DHCP is enabled.

You cannot edit LAN Port setting on this device because it has assigned to the venue which already has enabled DHCP service.
qEplfM: JP-AP service is affected due to high number of AP reboots
r2CU5S:
The DHCP exchange is failing because of a timeout waiting for a response from the DHCP server. This is typically caused by the following reasons:

  1. The DHCP server is offline.
  2. The DHCP server is unreachable on the LAN (a network path issue) or there is high network latency.
  3. The VLAN/DVLAN infrastructure is not properly configured on the SSID, AP, or switch ports.
  4. The DHCP server is overloaded and unable to reply.
  5. The DHCP helper IP address is not configured on the subnet.
rrNFNw: AP lost connection to controller for more than 7200 seconds
s5tGxo: Please enter a valid number between 0 and 65535
swJCKh:
In many cases with DHCP failure, each client device behaves differently, which causes a variety of unique failure symptoms. If the problem is affecting many users or lasting for a long time, it may be helpful to validate the end-to-end DHCP setup:

  1. Check DHCP server IP scopes are configured and enabled with available addresses.
  2. Check the network infrastructure is configured with proper VLANs (to the AP), IP helpers, or DHCP Proxy in place.
  3. Check for availability of DHCP servers and IP reachability by client devices.
  4. Check any recent changes in the DHCP infrastructure that may be leading to issues.
t7Y1lT: WPA2 is strong Wi-Fi security that is widely available on all mobile devices manufactured after 2006. WPA2 should be selected unless you have a specific reason to choose otherwise. <highlight> 6GHz radios are only supported with WPA3. </highlight>
tMSNXZ: Clients are failing association because the association request has unsupported or malformed security information in the WPA/RSN information element(s), which typically indicates interoperability issues.
taS9eS: The IP addresses you entered conflict with existing authentication server configuration in another network. Please change the IP address.
tba7nY:
For each group of reasons, corresponding recommendations are below:

  1. Turn off unused features - AVC, Wi-Fi Calling, Mesh, URL Filtering, Rogue client etc.
  2. Check the rate and volume of data requested through public API calls.
  3. Consider removing unnecessary events or reducing the duration of event storage.
  4. Check the rate and volume of user login requests.
  5. Address any alarms related to AP or switch connection status.

Generally memory and I/O intensive process are transient. If a sustained high memory usage is observed, please work with Ruckus customer team.
tvJbQP: JP-WPA3 is the highest level of Wi-Fi security available but is supported only by devices manufactured after 2019.
uDSCxx: Incorrect data timestamps are typically caused by NTP issues either on the controller or the underlying infrastructure.
uWx1Qp: High AP-RUCKUS Cloud connection failures in {scope}.
udk0yj: If the issue does not resolve on its own, check the traffic and client load of the affected APs to see if there is a persistent load issue. Packet captures may also help to confirm the behavior is initiated by the AP. If that is the case, and clients cannot remain connected, an AP reboot may be necessary.
uqoLDd: Cannot save threshold at organisation level. Please select a Venue or AP to set a threshold.
urCWaH: The connection is failing because of a mismatch in the connection state machine. Clients are attempting to associate prior to forming a successful open authentication.
v5rkH1: This incident impacted {count} {count, plural, one {AP model} other {AP models} }
v9+jd5: JP-EAP failures are high in {scope} impacting connectivity for {impact} of clients.
w6rFmt:
To resolve data timestamp issues, check the controller time for accuracy:

  1. Ensure that the NTP server is online and reachable.
  2. Execute a manual NTP sync to update the time.
  3. Check the underlying infrastructure (in a VM environment) to ensure the hypervisor is providing the correct time.
wNvwIx: This disconnect issue is happening because the device is being disassociated by the AP due to inactivity. The WLAN configuration includes an inactivity timeout, which allows the AP to disconnect client devices if it has not seen frames to/from the device for the duration of the timeout interval.
wYJqw/:
Invalid key data is an uncommon issue in the 4-way handshake. If this is happening, packet captures may be required to investigate the nature of invalid keys.

If the problem persists, check common situations that may have introduced this interoperability behavior:

  1. Are the impacted clients using problematic drivers or firmware?
  2. Was the firmware recently updated on impacted clients so as to introduce interoperability issues?
  3. Were new client types recently introduced into the environment?
xI4nIt: Connectivity is failing because the security type (cipher suite) requested by the client is not valid or is not supported by the AP/WLAN.
xKk/lt: JP-The network latency between the SZ nodes is unusually high.
xbKzeb: Block a client for <blockingPeriod></blockingPeriod> seconds after <failThreshold></failThreshold> repeat authentication failures within <checkPeriod></checkPeriod> seconds
xxIzVH: The connection exchange is failing because the 4-way handshake is taking too long, typically because of busy RF environmental conditions, or possibly due to high latency if using an external PSK authentication mechanism (like external DPSK).
yCDkU6: JP-Time to connect is greater than {threshold} in {scope}
yI8Rg+: This incident impacted {count} {count, plural, one {AP firmware} other {AP firmwares} }
yK/eML: The IP addresses you entered conflict with existing accounting server configuration in another network. Please change the IP address.
yKhFVq:
Though this issue is uncommon, it may occur due to unexpected configuration changes or incompatibilities:

  1. Are the impacted clients configured to use a WLAN type that mismatches the AP/SSID settings?
  2. Were devices recently upgraded with new firmware that may be introducing bugs?
  3. Was the WLAN configuration changed on the infrastructure?
ykBQn4: JP-Sub-optimal WAN throughput - speed mismatch between AP and peer device: {scope}
ymr68V: JP-Users are authorized through a captive portal in various methods
yxEwuj: This disconnect issue is happening because clients are sending unsupported frames (i.e. Class3) before forming a valid open association.
z/4kqd: Mgmt Group Cipher is not valid
zK1Tuz:
To remediate the problems identified above, follow the corresponding recommended actions:

  1. Ensure that PSE - PoE switch or PoE injector capacity and cumulative power requirements of all APs for full operation are appropriately matched.
  2. (Typical) Check the connectivity to the AP gateway and latency to RUCKUS Cloud. In rare cases it might indicate configuration corruption.
  3. (Typical) Check the connectivity to the AP gateway and latency to RUCKUS Cloud. Download time out is the main cause.
  4. RUCKUS Cloud can reboot the AP for multiple reasons. There could be an mishandled exception or catastrophic failure in a process, causing RUCKUS Cloud to reboot the AP. In these cases, an alarm is raised. Use RUCKUS Cloud alarm message, Alarm code: 302 and attribute field to understand and isolate this issue further.
zKrbuH: This event is a normal function of network load distribution and should not be a concern unless it persists in the network as a source of connection failures. A single incident of this type should not be a concern.
zifKlV: JP-Sub-optimal WAN throughput - speed mismatch between AP and peer device: {scope}.
zs74F6: This incident impacted {count} {count, plural, one {operating system} other {operating systems} }
